evidence: 76 out of 79 climatologists who "listed climate science as their area of expertise and who also have published more than 50% of their recent peer-reviewed papers on the subject of climate change" believed that mean global temperatures had risen compared to pre-1800s levels.

claim: less than half of published scientists endorse global warming.
label: refutes
evidence: scientists reach 100% consensus on anthropogenic global warming.

claim: tuvalu sea level isn't rising.
label: refutes
evidence: because of the low elevation, the islands that make up this nation are vulnerable to the effects of tropical cyclones and by the threat of current and future sea level rise.

claim: tuvalu sea level isn't rising.
label: refutes
evidence: tuvalu is also affected by perigean spring tide events which raise the sea level higher than a normal high tide.

claim: tuvalu sea level isn't rising.
label: refutes
evidence: tuvaluan leaders have been concerned about the effects of rising sea levels.

claim: renewables can't provide baseload power.
label: refutes
evidence: "supplying baseload power and reducing transmission requirements by interconnecting wind farms".

claim: renewables can't provide baseload power.
label: refutes
evidence: generating electrical power from geothermal resources requires no fuel while providing true baseload energy at a reliability rate that constantly exceeds 90%.

claim: renewables can't provide baseload power.
label: refutes
evidence: about 8% of total nameplate capacity) to be used as reliable, baseload electric power which can be relied on to handle peak loads, as long as minimum criteria are met for wind speed and turbine height.

claim: ice sheet losses are overestimated.
label: refutes
evidence: the greenland, and possibly the antarctic, ice sheets have been losing mass recently, because losses by ablation including outlet glaciers exceed accumulation of snowfall.

claim: ice sheet losses are overestimated.
label: refutes
evidence: the ipcc projects that ice mass loss from melting of the greenland ice sheet will continue to outpace accumulation of snowfall.

claim: ice sheet losses are overestimated.
label: refutes
evidence: accumulation of snowfall on the antarctic ice sheet is projected to outpace losses from melting.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.
label: refutes
evidence: the fast rate of the sea ice melting is resulting in the oceans absorbing and heating up the arctic.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.
label: refutes
evidence: the arctic is affected by current global warming, leading to arctic sea ice shrinkage, diminished ice in the greenland ice sheet, and arctic methane release as the permafrost thaws.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.
label: refutes
evidence: the effects of global warming in the arctic include rising temperatures, loss of sea ice, and melting of the greenland ice sheet.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.
label: refutes
evidence: release of methane and carbon dioxide stored in permafrost could cause abrupt and severe global warming, as they are potent greenhouse gases.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.
label: refutes
evidence: surface temperature increases are greatest in the arctic, which has contributed to the retreat of glaciers, permafrost, and sea ice.

claim: murry salby finds co2 rise is natural.
label: disputed
evidence: human activities have caused co 2 to increase above levels not seen in hundreds of thousands of years.

claim: murry salby finds co2 rise is natural.
label: disputed
evidence: climate change may be due to natural internal processes or external forcings such as modulations of the solar cycles, volcanic eruptions and persistent anthropogenic changes in the composition of the atmosphere or in land use."

claim: 97% consensus on human-caused global warming has been disproven.
label: refutes
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: 97% consensus on human-caused global warming has been disproven.
label: refutes
evidence: in a 2019 cbs poll, 64% of the us population said that climate change is a "crisis" or a "serious problem", with 44% saying human activity was a significant contributor.

claim: 97% consensus on human-caused global warming has been disproven.
label: refutes
evidence: 97% of the scientists surveyed agreed that global temperatures had increased during the past 100 years; 84% said they personally believed human-induced warming was occurring, and 74% agreed that "currently available scientific evidence" substantiated its occurrence.

claim: water vapor in the stratosphere stopped global warming.
label: supports
evidence: this process is enhanced by global warming, because warmer air holds more water vapor than colder air, so the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere increases as it is warmed by the greenhouse effect.

claim: water vapor in the stratosphere stopped global warming.
label: supports
evidence: an increase in temperature from greenhouse gases leading to increased water vapor (which is itself a greenhouse gas) causing further warming is a positive feedback, but not a runaway effect, on earth.

claim: adapting to global warming is cheaper than preventing it.
label: disputed
evidence: adaptation is especially important in developing countries since those countries are bearing the brunt of the effects of global warming.

claim: adapting to global warming is cheaper than preventing it.
label: disputed
evidence: successful adaptation is easier if there are substantial emission reductions.

claim: adapting to global warming is cheaper than preventing it.
label: disputed
evidence: adaptation is especially important in developing countries since they are predicted to bear the brunt of the effects of global warming.

claim: cern cloud experiment proved cosmic rays are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: "sun's shifts may cause global warming".

claim: cern cloud experiment proved cosmic rays are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: cern cloud experiment proved cosmic rays are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: he is known for his theory on the effects of cosmic rays on cloud formation as an indirect cause of global warming.

claim: cern cloud experiment proved cosmic rays are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: "cosmic rays blamed for global warming".

claim: antarctica is too cold to lose ice.
label: disputed
evidence: offshore, temperatures are also low enough that ice is formed from seawater through most of the year.

claim: antarctica is too cold to lose ice.
label: disputed
evidence: this ice sheet is constantly gaining ice from snowfall and losing ice through outflow to the sea.

claim: antarctica is too cold to lose ice.
label: disputed
evidence: the continent has about 90% of the world's ice (and thus about 70% of the world's fresh water).

claim: coral atolls grow as sea levels rise.
label: supports
evidence: gradual sea-level rise also allows for coral polyp activity to raise the atolls with the sea level.

claim: coral atolls grow as sea levels rise.
label: supports
evidence: as communities established themselves, the reefs grew upwards, pacing rising sea levels.

claim: coral atolls grow as sea levels rise.
label: supports
evidence: healthy tropical coral reefs grow horizontally from 1 to 3 cm (0.39 to 1.18 in) per year, and grow vertically anywhere from 1 to 25 cm (0.39 to 9.84 in) per year; however, they grow only at depths shallower than 150 m (490 ft) because of their need for sunlight, and cannot grow above sea level.

claim: coral atolls grow as sea levels rise.
label: supports
evidence: atolls may also be formed by the sinking of the seabed or rising of the sea level.

claim: co2 increase is natural, not human-caused.
label: refutes
evidence: while co 2 absorption and release is always happening as a result of natural processes, the recent rise in co 2 levels in the atmosphere is known to be mainly due to human (anthropogenic) activity.

claim: co2 increase is natural, not human-caused.
label: refutes
evidence: human activity since the industrial revolution has increased the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, leading to increased radiative forcing from co2, methane, tropospheric ozone, cfcs, and nitrous oxide.

claim: co2 increase is natural, not human-caused.
label: refutes
evidence: [clarification needed] this increase is the result of human activities by burning fossil fuels, deforestation and forest degradation in tropical and boreal regions.

claim: co2 increase is natural, not human-caused.
label: refutes
evidence: it is likely that anthropogenic (i.e., human-induced) warming, such as that due to elevated greenhouse gas levels, has had a discernible influence on many physical and biological systems.

claim: scientists retracted claim that sea levels are rising.
label: refutes
evidence: sea level rise will continue over many centuries.

claim: scientists retracted claim that sea levels are rising.
label: refutes
evidence: the effects of global warming include rising sea levels, regional changes in precipitation, more frequent extreme weather events such as heat waves, and expansion of deserts.

claim: scientists retracted claim that sea levels are rising.
label: refutes
evidence: since at least the start of the 20th century, the average global sea level has been rising.

claim: renewable energy investment kills jobs.
label: refutes
evidence: some 2.3 million people have found renewable energy jobs in recent years, and projected investments of $630 billion by 2030 would translate into at least 20 million additional jobs.

claim: renewable energy investment kills jobs.
label: refutes
evidence: in the context of the current world economic crisis, many experts now argue that a massive push to develop renewable sources of energy could create millions of new jobs and help the economy recover while simultaneously improving the environment, increasing labour conditions in poor economies, and strengthening energy and food security.

claim: renewable energy investment kills jobs.
label: refutes
evidence: a key benefit that this investment growth brings is a growth in jobs.

claim: renewable energy investment kills jobs.
label: refutes
evidence: globally there are an estimated 7.7 million jobs associated with the renewable energy industries, with solar photovoltaics being the largest renewable employer.

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.
label: refutes
evidence: if iceberg calving has happened as an average, greenland lost 294 gt of its mass during 2007 (one km3 of ice weighs about 0.9 gt).

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.
label: refutes
evidence: findings show that greenland has lost 3.8 trillion tonnes of ice since 1992, enough to raise sea levels by almost 11mm (1.06cm).

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.
label: refutes
evidence: the rate of ice loss has increased from an average of 33 billion tonnes a year in the 1990s, to 254 billion tonnes a year in the last decade.

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.
label: refutes
evidence: between 2000 and 2016, 29 % of the glacierized area was lost, the remaining area estimated at around 1,300 km2 (500 sq mi).

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.
label: refutes
evidence: between then and 2010, the mountain lost 80 percent of its ice — two-thirds of which since another scientific expedition in the 1970s.

claim: arctic sea ice extent was lower in the past.
label: refutes
evidence: the arctic sea ice september minimum extent (i.e., area with at least 15% sea ice coverage) reached new record lows in 2002, 2005, 2007, and 2012.

claim: arctic sea ice extent was lower in the past.
label: refutes
evidence: in comparison to the extended record, the sea-ice extent in the polar region by september 2007 was only half the recorded mass that had been estimated to exist within the 1950–1970 period.

claim: arctic sea ice extent was lower in the past.
label: refutes
evidence: arctic sea ice extent ice hit an all-time low in september 2012, when the ice was determined to cover only 24% of the arctic ocean, offsetting the previous low of 29% in 2007.

claim: climate change isn't increasing extreme weather damage costs.
label: refutes
evidence: many analyses, such as that of the stern review presented to the british government, have predicted reductions by several percent of world gross domestic product due to climate related costs such as dealing with increased extreme weather events and stresses to low-lying areas due to sea level rises.

claim: climate change isn't increasing extreme weather damage costs.
label: refutes
evidence: global losses reveal rapidly rising costs due to extreme weather-related events since the 1970s.

claim: climate change isn't increasing extreme weather damage costs.
label: refutes
evidence: "impacts [of climate change] will very likely increase due to increased frequencies and intensities of some extreme weather events".

claim: ipcc human-caused global warming attribution confidence is unfounded.
label: refutes
evidence: there is a clear human influence on the climate it is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of observed warming since 1950, with the level of confidence having increased since the fourth report.

claim: ipcc human-caused global warming attribution confidence is unfounded.
label: refutes
evidence: since the mid-20th century, most of the observed warming is "likely" (greater than 66% probability, based on expert judgement) due to human activities.

claim: great barrier reef is in good shape.
label: disputed

claim: great barrier reef is in good shape.
label: disputed
evidence: the great barrier reef can be seen from outer space and is the world's biggest single structure made by living organisms.

claim: great barrier reef is in good shape.
label: disputed
evidence: crescentic reefs are the most common shape of reef in the middle of the system, for example the reefs surrounding lizard island.

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.
label: supports
evidence: climate change also increases droughts and heat waves that inhibit plant growth, which makes it uncertain whether this balancing feedback will persist in the future.

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.
label: supports
evidence: many regions have probably already seen increases in warm spells and heat waves, and it is virtually certain that these changes will continue over the 21st century.

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.
label: supports
evidence: since the 1950s, droughts and heat waves have appeared simultaneously with increasing frequency.

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.
label: supports
evidence: the effects of global warming include rising sea levels, regional changes in precipitation, more frequent extreme weather events such as heat waves, and expansion of deserts.

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.
label: supports
evidence: global warming boosts the probability of extreme weather events, like heat waves, far more than it boosts more moderate events.

claim: climate reacts to whatever forces it to change at the time; humans are now the dominant forcing.
label: supports
evidence: human activities can also impose forcings, for example, through changing the composition of the atmosphere.

claim: climate reacts to whatever forces it to change at the time; humans are now the dominant forcing.
label: supports
evidence: volcanic eruptions, solar variations and anthropogenic changes in the composition of the atmosphere and land use change are external forcings.

claim: climate reacts to whatever forces it to change at the time; humans are now the dominant forcing.
label: supports
evidence: these external forcings can be natural, such as variations in solar intensity and volcanic eruptions, or caused by humans.

claim: climate reacts to whatever forces it to change at the time; humans are now the dominant forcing.
label: supports
evidence: other changes are caused by external forcings.

claim: in the last 35 years of global warming, sun and climate have been going in opposite directions.
label: supports
evidence: over the past five decades there has been a global warming of approximately 0.65 °c (1.17 °f) at the earth's surface (see historical temperature record).

claim: in the last 35 years of global warming, sun and climate have been going in opposite directions.
label: supports
evidence: climate change may occur over long and short timescales from a variety of factors; recent warming is discussed in global warming.

claim: in the last 35 years of global warming, sun and climate have been going in opposite directions.
label: supports
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: 97% of climate experts agree humans are causing global warming.

evidence: climate scientists have reached a consensus that the earth is undergoing significant anthropogenic (human-induced) global warming.

claim: 97% of climate experts agree humans are causing global warming.

claim: the warming trend is the same in rural and urban areas, measured by thermometers and satellites.
label: disputed
evidence: for example, urban and rural trends are very similar.

claim: the warming trend is the same in rural and urban areas, measured by thermometers and satellites.
label: disputed
evidence: after trends were adjusted in urban weather stations around the world to match rural stations in their regions, in an effort to homogenise the temperature record, in 42 percent of cases, cities were getting cooler relative to their surroundings rather than warmer.

claim: satellites measure antarctica losing land ice at an accelerating rate.
label: disputed
evidence: "a 40-y record reveals gradual antarctic sea ice increases followed by decreases at rates far exceeding the rates seen in the arctic".

claim: satellites measure antarctica losing land ice at an accelerating rate.
label: disputed

claim: satellites measure antarctica losing land ice at an accelerating rate.
label: disputed
evidence: a satellite record revealed that the overall increase in antarctic sea ice extents reversed in 2014, with rapid rates of decrease in 2014–2017 reducing the antarctic sea ice extents to their lowest values in the 40-y record.

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.
label: supports

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.
label: supports

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.
label: supports
evidence: the story is scientifically accurate and yet should be understandable to the public, a public that is less and less drawn to science."

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.
label: supports
evidence: earth in the balance: ecology and the human spirit (isbn 0-452-26935-0, paperback isbn 1-85383-743-1) is a 1992 book written by al gore, published in june 1992, shortly before he was elected vice president in the 1992 presidential election.

claim: most glaciers are retreating, posing a serious problem for millions who rely on glaciers for water.
label: supports
evidence: earth's glaciers are expected to melt within the next forty years, greatly decreasing fresh water flow in the hotter times of the year, causing everyone to depend on rainwater, resulting in large shortages and fluctuations in fresh water availability which largely effects agriculture, power supply, and human health and well-being.
article: effects of global warming on human health

claim: most glaciers are retreating, posing a serious problem for millions who rely on glaciers for water.
label: supports
evidence: following the little ice age's end around 1850, glaciers around the earth have retreated substantially.

claim: most glaciers are retreating, posing a serious problem for millions who rely on glaciers for water.
label: supports

claim: most glaciers are retreating, posing a serious problem for millions who rely on glaciers for water.
label: supports
evidence: climate change has caused receding glaciers, reduced stream and river flow, and shrinking lakes and ponds.

claim: cosmic rays show no trend over the last 30 years & have had little impact on recent global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: cosmic rays show no trend over the last 30 years & have had little impact on recent global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: estimated that the residual effects of the prolonged high solar activity during the last 30 years account for between 16% and 36% of warming from 1950 to 1999.

claim: extreme weather events are being made more frequent and worse by global warming.
label: supports
evidence: impacts include the direct effects of extreme weather, leading to injury and loss of life; and indirect effects, such as undernutrition brought on by crop failures.

claim: extreme weather events are being made more frequent and worse by global warming.
label: supports
evidence: the effects of global warming include rising sea levels, regional changes in precipitation, more frequent extreme weather events such as heat waves, and expansion of deserts.

claim: extreme weather events are being made more frequent and worse by global warming.
label: supports
evidence: global warming boosts the probability of extreme weather events, like heat waves, far more than it boosts more moderate events.

claim: extreme weather events are being made more frequent and worse by global warming.
label: supports
evidence: climate change caused by human activities that emit greenhouse gases into the air is expected to affect the frequency of extreme weather events such as drought, extreme temperatures, flooding, high winds, and severe storms.

claim: a variety of different measurements find steadily rising sea levels over the past century.
label: supports
evidence: since at least the start of the 20th century, the average global sea level has been rising.

claim: a variety of different measurements find steadily rising sea levels over the past century.
label: supports
evidence: more precise data gathered from satellite radar measurements reveal an accelerating rise of 7.5 cm (3.0 in) from 1993 to 2017, which is a trend of roughly 30 cm (12 in) per century.

claim: a variety of different measurements find steadily rising sea levels over the past century.
label: supports
evidence: since the last glacial maximum about 20,000 years ago, the sea level has risen by more than 125 metres (410 ft), with rates varying from less than a mm/year to 40+ mm/year, as a result of melting ice sheets over canada and eurasia.

claim: urban and rural regions show the same warming trend.

claim: urban and rural regions show the same warming trend.
label: disputed
evidence: not all cities show a warming relative to their rural surroundings.

claim: the most recent ocean measurements show consistent warming.
label: supports
evidence: the warming evident in the instrumental temperature record is consistent with a wide range of observations, documented by many independent scientific groups; for example, in most continental regions the frequency and intensity of heavy precipitation has increased.

claim: the most recent ocean measurements show consistent warming.
label: supports
evidence: from 1961 to 2003, the global ocean temperature has risen by 0.10 °c from the surface to a depth of 700 m. there is variability both year-to-year and over longer time scales, with global ocean heat content observations showing high rates of warming for 1991 to 2003, but some cooling from 2003 to 2007.

claim: the most recent ocean measurements show consistent warming.
label: supports
evidence: "warming of the climate system is unequivocal, as is now evident from observations of increases in global average air and ocean temperatures, widespread melting of snow and ice and rising global average sea level."

claim: ancient natural cycles are irrelevant for attributing recent global warming to humans.
label: disputed
evidence: there is a scientific consensus linking human activities to global warming due to industrial carbon dioxide emissions.

claim: ancient natural cycles are irrelevant for attributing recent global warming to humans.
label: disputed
evidence: attributing detected temperature changes and extreme events to human-caused increases in greenhouse gases requires scientists to rule out known internal climate variability and natural external forcings.

claim: the natural cycle adds and removes co2 to keep a balance; humans add extra co2 without removing any.
label: supports
evidence: the co 2 is removed after combustion of fossil fuels, but before the flue gas is expanded to atmospheric pressure.

claim: the natural cycle adds and removes co2 to keep a balance; humans add extra co2 without removing any.
label: supports
evidence: since the industrial revolution, human activity has modified the carbon cycle by changing its components' functions and directly adding carbon to the atmosphere.

claim: the natural cycle adds and removes co2 to keep a balance; humans add extra co2 without removing any.
label: supports
evidence: another direct human impact on the carbon cycle is the chemical process of calcination of limestone for clinker production, which releases co 2.

claim: the natural cycle adds and removes co2 to keep a balance; humans add extra co2 without removing any.
label: supports
evidence: various carbon dioxide scrubbing processes have been proposed to remove co 2 from the air, usually using a variant of the kraft process.

claim: numerous papers have documented how ipcc predictions are more likely to underestimate the climate response.
label: disputed

claim: numerous papers have documented how ipcc predictions are more likely to underestimate the climate response.
label: disputed
evidence: some critics have contended that the ipcc reports tend to be conservative by consistently underestimating the pace and impacts of global warming, and report only the "lowest common denominator" findings.

claim: numerous papers have documented how ipcc predictions are more likely to underestimate the climate response.
label: disputed
evidence: another example of scientific research which suggests that previous estimates by the ipcc, far from overstating dangers and risks, have actually understated them is a study on projected rises in sea levels.

claim: rising co2 increases atmospheric water vapor, which makes global warming much worse.
label: supports
evidence: increases in atmospheric concentrations of co 2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases such as methane, nitrous oxide and ozone have correspondingly strengthened their absorption and emission of infrared radiation, causing the rise in average global temperature since the mid-20th century.

claim: rising co2 increases atmospheric water vapor, which makes global warming much worse.
label: supports
evidence: not only do increasing carbon dioxide concentrations lead to increases in global surface temperature, but increasing global temperatures also cause increasing concentrations of carbon dioxide.

claim: rising co2 increases atmospheric water vapor, which makes global warming much worse.

evidence: higher atmospheric co2 concentrations have led to an increase in dissolved co2, which causes ocean acidification.

claim: polar bears are in danger of extinction as well as many other species.

claim: polar bears are in danger of extinction as well as many other species.
label: supports
evidence: the key danger posed by climate change is malnutrition or starvation due to habitat loss.

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.

evidence: play media satellite measurements of greenland's ice cover from 1979 to 2009 reveals a trend of increased melting.

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.

evidence: this glacier was discovered in 2002 to be shrinking rapidly, and by 2007 had completely melted away, leaving the exposed island.

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.
label: supports
evidence: findings show that greenland has lost 3.8 trillion tonnes of ice since 1992, enough to raise sea levels by almost 11mm (1.06cm).

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.

claim: the effects of enhanced co2 on terrestrial plants are variable and complex and dependent on numerous factors.

claim: the effects of enhanced co2 on terrestrial plants are variable and complex and dependent on numerous factors.
label: supports
evidence: carbon fixation is a biochemical process by which atmospheric carbon dioxide is incorporated by plants, algae and (cyanobacteria) into energy-rich organic molecules such as glucose, thus creating their own food by photosynthesis.

claim: the effects of enhanced co2 on terrestrial plants are variable and complex and dependent on numerous factors.
label: supports
evidence: the concentration of secondary metabolites such as phenylpropanoids and flavonoids can also be altered in plants exposed to high concentrations of co 2.

claim: thick arctic sea ice is in rapid retreat.
label: supports
evidence: the holocene glacial retreat is a geographical phenomenon that involved the global deglaciation of glaciers that previously had advanced during the last glacial maximum.

claim: thick arctic sea ice is in rapid retreat.
label: supports
evidence: the retreat of the arctic sea ice will accelerate global warming, as less ice cover reflects less solar radiation, and may have serious climate implications by contributing to arctic cyclone generation.

claim: thick arctic sea ice is in rapid retreat.

claim: there is long-term correlation between co2 and global temperature; other effects are short-term.

claim: there is long-term correlation between co2 and global temperature; other effects are short-term.
label: supports
evidence: during the glacial cycles, there was a high correlation between co 2 concentrations and temperatures.

claim: there is long-term correlation between co2 and global temperature; other effects are short-term.
label: supports
evidence: this trend could be extrapolated to continue into the future, possibly leading to a full ice age, but the twentieth-century instrumental temperature record shows a sudden reversal of this trend, with a rise in global temperatures attributed to greenhouse gas emissions.

claim: there is long-term correlation between co2 and global temperature; other effects are short-term.
label: supports
evidence: there is also a close correlation between co2 and temperature, where co2 has a strong control over global temperatures in earth history.

claim: scientists have determined that the factors which caused the little ice age cooling are not currently causing global warming.
label: supports
evidence: historical patterns of warming and cooling, like the medieval climate anomaly and the little ice age, were not as synchronous as current warming, but may have reached temperatures as high as those of the late-20th century in a limited set of regions.

claim: scientists have determined that the factors which caused the little ice age cooling are not currently causing global warming.
label: supports
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: scientists have determined that the factors which caused the little ice age cooling are not currently causing global warming.

evidence: the temperature data was updated in 2006 to report that temperatures are now 0.8 °c warmer than a century ago, and concluded that the recent global warming is a real climate change and not an artifact from the urban heat island effect.

claim: global temperature is still rising and 2010 was the hottest recorded.

claim: global temperature is still rising and 2010 was the hottest recorded.

evidence: global warming is the long-term rise in the average temperature of the earth's climate system.

claim: global temperature is still rising and 2010 was the hottest recorded.

claim: warmer seasons or triennial phases are followed by an atmosphere that is rich in co2, reflecting the gas solving or exsolving from water, and not photosynthesis activity.

claim: warmer seasons or triennial phases are followed by an atmosphere that is rich in co2, reflecting the gas solving or exsolving from water, and not photosynthesis activity.

claim: water vapor helps trap heat, and is a far the strongest of the major greenhouse gases, contributing 36–72 percent of the greenhouse effect.

claim: water vapor helps trap heat, and is a far the strongest of the major greenhouse gases, contributing 36–72 percent of the greenhouse effect.

claim: thus rather than a "doomsday" cycle of runaway warming, mother earth appears surprisingly tolerant of carbon, decreasing atmospheric levels of water vapor -- a more effective greenhouse gas -- to compensate.
label: refutes
evidence: eventually other earth processes offset these positive feedbacks, stabilizing the global temperature at a new equilibrium and preventing the loss of earth's water through a venus-like runaway greenhouse effect.

claim: thus rather than a "doomsday" cycle of runaway warming, mother earth appears surprisingly tolerant of carbon, decreasing atmospheric levels of water vapor -- a more effective greenhouse gas -- to compensate.
label: refutes

claim: thus rather than a "doomsday" cycle of runaway warming, mother earth appears surprisingly tolerant of carbon, decreasing atmospheric levels of water vapor -- a more effective greenhouse gas -- to compensate.
